sense.gloss: southern barbarians (name used in ancient China for non-Chinese ethnic groups to the south)
South-East Asian countries (in the late-Muromachi and Edo periods)
Western Europe (esp. Spain and Portugal and their South-East Asian colonies; late-Muromachi and Edo periods)
foreign (of goods from South-East Asia and Western Europe), exotic (esp. in a Western European or South-East Asian style)
nanban, dish prepared using chili peppers and Welsh onions
thrusting the right foot and right arm forward at the same time (or left foot and left arm; in kabuki, dance, puppetry, etc.)
act of barbarity, barbarism, brutality, savagery
foolhardiness, recklessness, savage valour, savage valor, brute courage
Western European (esp. the Spanish and the Portuguese), southern barbarian
foreign ship (esp. from Spain and Portugal from the late Muromachi period to the early Edo period), Nanban trade ship
scruffy, unconcerned about one's personal appearance
languages spoken by the nanban during the Edo Period (e.g. Spanish, Portuguese, Dutch)
aboriginal Taiwanese tribes outside Qing China's jurisdiction
the barbarians beyond the borders of old China
imported to Japan by early European traders
primitive and barbarous, uncivilized and barbaric
Nanban trade, Japanese trade with Spain and Portugal (1543-1641)
confections adopted from Portugal, Spain, etc. during the Muromachi period and since Japanized
noodles with duck meat and Welsh onions
sauteed vegetables with fish or poultry made into a stew
poultry or fish stew with chili peppers and Welsh onions mixed in
fried chicken with vinegar and tartar sauce
roasted or deep-fried fish or meat, marinated in a spicy sauce

r_ele.r: ばんしょくのあらそい

sense.gloss: fighting over nothing, making a mountain out of a molehill
Johnson grass (Sorghum halepense), Johnsongrass, Egyptian millet
berry catchfly (Silene baccifera), Cucubalus baccifer (former name)
Christian churches built in Japan in the second half of the 16th century
incense variety used in kōdō (orig. from eastern India)
painted folding screen with scenes of early European visitors to Japan

sdata.j: ↑教養↑↓きょうよう↓の↑点↑↓てん↓では↑彼↑↓かれ↓らは↑野蛮↑↓やばん↓↑人↑↓じん↓と↑同↑↓おな↓じ↑程度↑↓ていど↓だ。
sdata.e: In culture, they are on the same plane as savages.

sdata.j: ↑泣↑↓な↓いたことがない↑若者↑↓わかもの↓は↑野蛮↑↓やばん↓↑人↑↓じん↓であり、↑笑↑↓わら↓おうとしない↑老人↑↓ろうじん↓は↑愚者↑↓ぐしゃ↓である。
sdata.e: The young man who has not wept is a savage, and the old man who will not laugh is a fool.

sdata.j: ↑音楽↑↓おんがく↓は↑野蛮↑↓やばん↓↑人↑↓じん↓の↑胸↑↓むね↓をなだめすかす↑魅力↑↓みりょく↓がある。
sdata.e: Music has charms to soothe a savage breast.

sdata.j: ↑移住↑↓いじゅう↓↑者↑↓しゃ↓の↑部落↑↓ぶらく↓が↑野蛮↑↓やばん↓↑人↑↓じん↓によって↑征服↑↓せいふく↓され、↑移住↑↓いじゅう↓↑者↑↓しゃ↓の↑希望↑↓きぼう↓も↑生活↑↓せいかつ↓も↑土壇場↑↓どたんば↓にきた↑時↑↓とき↓、↑長↑↓なが↓い↑歳月↑↓さいげつ↓をかけての↑不幸↑↓ふこう↓とのたたかいに↑終止符↑↓しゅうしふ↓がうたれた。
sdata.e: Years of resistance to misfortune ended when the settlers' village was overcome by the savages and their hopes and lives came to the bitter end.

sdata.j: まだ↑野蛮↑↓やばん↓な↑国↑↓くに↓がある。
↑指↑↓ゆび↓を↑使↑↓つか↓うことは↑野蛮↑↓やばん↓なのだろうか。
↑人間↑↓にんげん↓の↑野蛮↑↓やばん↓↑性↑↓せい↓は↑決↑↓けっ↓して↑根絶↑↓こんぜつ↓できない。
sdata.e: The savage in man is never quite eradicated.

sdata.j: ↑彼↑↓かれ↓は↑全↑↓まった↓くの↑野蛮↑↓やばん↓↑人↑↓じん↓だ。
↑復讐↑↓ふくしゅう↓において、↑恋愛↑↓れんあい↓において、↑女↑↓おんな↓は↑男↑↓おとこ↓よりも↑野蛮↑↓やばん↓である。
sdata.e: In revenge and in love woman is more barbarous than man is.

sdata.j: ↑野蛮↑↓やばん↓な↑男↑↓おとこ↓がわたしの↑高価↑↓こうか↓な↑宝石↑↓ほうせき↓をうばって↑逃走↑↓とうそう↓した。
sdata.e: The savage robbed me of my precious jewels and ran away.

sdata.j: ↑己↑↓おのれ↓の↑慣習↑↓かんしゅう↓でないものを、↑人↑↓ひと↓は↑野蛮↑↓やばん↓と↑呼↑↓よ↓ぶ。
sdata.e: Each man calls barbarism whatever is not his own practice.

sdata.j: ↑俺↑↓おれ↓は↑青二才↑↓あおにさい↓の↑頃↑↓ころ↓は↑蛮↑↓ばん↓カラぶって↑真夏↑↓まなつ↓に↑二↑↓に↓↑週間↑↓しゅうかん↓ほど、お↑風呂↑↓ふろ↓に↑入↑↓はい↓らなかったこともあった。
sdata.e: When I was young, I was a bit scruffy and there were times when I didn't take a bath for up to two weeks during the summer.

sdata.j: ↑文明↑↓ぶんめい↓↑人↑↓じん↓も↑一皮↑↓ひとかわ↓むけば↑野蛮↑↓やばん↓↑人↑↓じん↓。
sdata.e: Look under the skin of a civilized man and you will find a barbarian.
